metadata.sermon_start_end: When someone has achieved something noteworthy, one of the first questions put to that person inquires how the success was attained. When a man or a woman reaches an unusually advanced age, reporters want to know, "How did you live to be a hundred or a hundred and five?" [...] Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life: and I will dwell in the house of the Lord for ever. (Psalm 23)

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Psalm 16:8 as a springboard but fails to treat it as a specific, unique word. Instead of finding what is 'nowhere else' in this text, the preacher treats it as a general religious principle that is then supported by quoting other, more famous Psalms (1, 23, 51). The sermon becomes a speech about 'the presence of God' rather than an exposition of the specific logic of Psalm 16.
quotes: The author of the sixteenth psalm was not slow to tell us how he found spiritual power and assurance.
The writer who wrote the words... might well be the same author of the words in the fifty-first psalm
The psalmist who wrote our text... may well have been the same who was enabled... to write these words [Psalm 23]
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Cease the 'harmonic' method of using other Psalms to explain the text. Focus exclusively on the unique vocabulary and theological structure of Psalm 16:8â€”specifically the 'right hand' and the concept of not being 'moved'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of linguistic or historical-critical study. The preacher does not engage with the Hebrew text or the specific religious-historical context of Israel. The 'exposition' is replaced by anecdotal reflections on aging and success.
quotes: The best human answer is that technique can be taught; art cannot.
The oldster knows that a kind of game is being played
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: The preacher must utilize Hebrew exegesis to explain what 'setting the Lord before me' meant in the cultic or personal piety of ancient Israel, rather than using modern psychological categories of 'success'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its imagery (new cars, corncob pipes, aging) but remains general in its theological demand. It touches on the 'zeitgeist' of success-seeking but often veers into moralism or sentimentality rather than a specific application of the text's unique claim.
quotes: The new car? It makes us feel successful. The new clothes? They give us a sense of well-being.
We are Peter, afraid of public opinion around us. We are the crowd ready to dance to any tune.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the application directly to the text's promise of stability ('not be moved') in the face of specific modern instabilities, rather than general moral failures.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a thematic essay than an interwoven exposition. Because the exposition is nearly non-existent, the application stands alone as a series of reflections triggered by the text's theme, rather than being drawn out of the text's specific movement.
quotes: Now, here is a man who seems calm, poised... The reporters crowd in upon him: tell us how it is done.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Structure the sermon so that the discovery of the text's meaning and the discovery of the hearer's situation happen simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon effectively utilizes the categories of misery (sin, loathsome creatures) and the need for redemption. It avoids being 'too objective' by addressing the human subject directly. However, the 'gratitude' section leans toward human 'aspiration' and 'stretching' rather than a Spirit-awakened response to grace.
quotes: we see ourselves as loathsome creatures who by the mercy of God and the work of Christ may be made useful instruments
To slump and to quit, to become morally flabby... is not what our humanity is all about
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure that 'gratitude' is framed as a response to God's act, not a moralistic call to 'be up and doing' or to avoid being 'morally flabby'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point. The preacher explicitly mentions the possibility of being 'lost' and the reality of 'hell,' taking the hearer's choices and the urgency of the spiritual life seriously. It avoids the 'liberal' trap of making everything safe.
quotes: Men and women... are racing to hell, but we are not in an agony of prayer for them.
She was going to hell for sure. | am not out to prove anything, but this was an interesting difference
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Anchor the 'two ways' more firmly in the text of Psalm 16 (which contrasts the Lord with other gods/sorrows) rather than general warnings about hell.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' and the 'work of Christ' is noted, but the connection to the Old Testament text is superficial. The sermon uses Christ as a necessary theological 'add-on' rather than showing how the Psalm itself points toward the one Lord.
quotes: It is a mockery of the Lord Jesus Christ who came that we might have life fully and abundantly
by the mercy of God and the work of Christ may be made useful instruments
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Apply the 'doctrine of the two natures' by showing how Christ is the only one who truly 'set the Lord always before Him' and was 'not moved' even in death.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,450 words, the sermon would take roughly 14-15 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth. The sermon feels like a series of anecdotes rather than a deep theological exploration.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the substantive exegetical and dogmatic weight to extend the sermon beyond 20 minutes, allowing for 'depth through breadth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to a lack of specific exegesis and insufficient length. It functions as a thematic address on spiritual success rather than an exposition of Psalm 16:8. While it correctly identifies human misery and the seriousness of the 'two ways,' it relies too heavily on anecdotal evidence and the 'harmonization' of various Psalms rather than wrestling with the unique word of the chosen pericope.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'two ways' and the reality of being lost, avoiding modern sentimentality.
Effective use of psychological categories (misery, desire for success) to engage the hearer's subjecthood.
weaknesses: Total absence of original language exegesis or historical context.
Failure to identify the 'unique' point of Psalm 16:8, treating it as a general religious truth.
Duration is significantly below the 20-minute threshold required for homiletical depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It is a religious speech that uses a Bible passage as a pretext for general spiritual reflections. It lacks the 'bicycle mechanic's' precision in mounting the wheel of the specific text.
